tn.ref: all the men of Judah and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem
tn.text: This is a generalization. AT: "many other people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This merism includes everyone in between. AT: "from the least important to the most important" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: He then read in their hearing
tn.text: "Then the king read aloud so that they could hear"
This can be translated in active form. AT: "that Hilkiah had found" (See: [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:22:08|22:8]]) or "that they had found" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The way a person lives is spoken of as if that person were walking on a path, and "to walk after" someone is a metonym for doing what that other person does or wants others to do. AT: "live obeying Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]]

tn.ref: his commandments, his regulations, and his statutes
tn.text: These words all share similar meanings. Together they emphasize everything that Yahweh had commanded in the law. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: with all his heart and all his soul
tn.text: The idiom "with all his heart" means "completely" and "with all his soul" means "with all his being." These two phrases have similar meanings. AT: "with all his being" or "with all his energy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: that were written in this book
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "that they had written in this book" or "that this book contained" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This idiom means to "obey the terms of the covenant." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"the other priests who served him"
men who guarded the gates to the temple

tn.ref: for Baal ... for all the stars
tn.text: "so people could use them to worship Baal ... so people could use them to worship all the stars"

tn.ref: He burned ... and carried ... He got rid
tn.text: The two instances of "He" refer to Josiah, but It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people, perhaps Hilkiah and "the priests under him" (23:4), might have helped Josiah do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
names of places (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: to Baal, to the sun and the moon, to the planets, and to all the stars
tn.text: "as a way to worship Baal, the sun and the moon, the planets, and all the stars"
This continues to tell what King Josiah did in response to the message from Yahweh.

tn.ref: He brought out ... and burned it ... He beat it ... and threw ... He cleared
tn.text: All instances of "He" refer to Josiah, but it might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people, perhaps Hilkiah and "the priests under him" ([[:en:bible:notes:2ki:23:04|23:4]]), might have helped Josiah do these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"made clothes"

tn.ref: Josiah brought ... and defiled ... He destroyed
tn.text: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people, perhaps Hilkiah and "the priests under him" ([[:en:bible:notes:2ki:23:04|23:4]]), might have helped Josiah do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
names of places (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"the city ruler named Joshua" or "the city leader named Joshua." This is a different Joshua from the Joshua in the Old Testament Book of Joshua.
Here "brothers" refers to their fellow priests who served at the temple.
place names (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: put his son or his daughter into the fire as a sacrifice to Molech
tn.text: "put his son or his daughter in the fire and burn them as an offering to Molech"

It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people, perhaps Hilkiah and "the priests under him" ([[:en:bible:notes:2ki:23:04|23:4]]), might have helped Josiah do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Possible meanings are 1) real horses or 2) statues of horses.

a man's name (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Josiah the king destroyed ... smashed ... threw ... ruined ... broke ... cut down ... filled
tn.text: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people, perhaps Hilkiah and "the priests under him" ([[:en:bible:notes:2ki:23:04|23:4]]), helped Josiah do these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
place name. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:23:04|23:4]].  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: filled those places with the bones of human beings
tn.text: "covered the ground with human bones so people could not use it as a shrine anymore"

tn.ref: Josiah also completely destroyed ... He also burned ... and beat ... He also burned
tn.text: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people, perhaps Hilkiah and "the priests under him" ([[:en:bible:notes:2ki:23:04|23:4]]), might have helped Josiah do these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"had said that these things would happen"
marker or statue that honors a person. A tomb (UDB) is one kind of monument.

tn.ref: So they let his bones alone, along with the bones of
tn.text: "So they did not touch his bones or the bones of"

tn.ref: Josiah removed ... He did ... He slaughtered ... he burned
tn.text: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people, perhaps Hilkiah and "the priests under him" ([[:en:bible:notes:2ki:23:04|23:4]]), might have helped Josiah do these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"what he had done"

tn.ref: he burned human bones on them
tn.text: "he burned human bones on them so no one would use them again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"You must celebrate the Passover"

tn.ref: Such a Passover celebration had never been held from the days of
tn.text: "The descendants of Israel had not celebrated the Passover festival in such a great way in the time of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The name "Israel" is a metonym for "the descendants of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the days of the kings of Israel or Judah
tn.text: "the time when the people of Israel had their own king and the people of Judah had their own king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: this Passover of Yahweh was celebrated
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "the people of Judah celebrated this Passover of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"forced those ... spirits to leave" or "made a law that those ... spirits had to leave"

tn.ref: those who talked with the dead or with spirits
tn.text: Similar words, "those who talked with the dead and ... those who talked with spirits," appear in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:21:04|21:6]].
things that people wrongly believe have special power
"who gave himself completely to Yahweh"

tn.ref: Nor did any king like Josiah arise after him
tn.text: "And since then there has never been a king who was like Josiah"
The writer uses this word to show that even though all of these things that Josiah did were good, Yahweh was still angry with Judah.

tn.ref: Yahweh did not turn from the fierceness of his great wrath, which had been kindled against
tn.text: Fire is a metaphor for anger, and starting a fire is a metaphor for becoming angry. The abstract nouns "fierceness" and "wrath" can be translated as adjectives. This can be translated in active form. AT: "Yahweh did not turn from the fierceness of his great wrath, which he had kindled against" or "Yahweh did not stop being fierce because he was angry with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"had caused him to be angry"
"from where I am" or "from being near me"
The name is a metonym for the honor that people should give to the person. AT: "People should worship me there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This can be expressed in active form and assumes that the answer is positive. The question is rhetorical and is used for emphasis. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:08:22|8:23]]. AT: "you can find them ... Judah." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: In his days, Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt
tn.text: "During the time Josiah was king of Egypt, Pharaoh Neco"
Neco is the name of a man. Megiddo is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
three years old** - "23 years old" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This is a woman's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Jehoahaz did what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: The nominal adjective "evil" can be translated as a relative clause "things that ... evil." Here Yahweh's "sight" refers to how he judges or decides on the value of something. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "He did things that Yahweh said were evil" or "He did the things that Yahweh considers evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

"people of the land of Judah." Possible meanings are 1) "the people who lived in the land of Judah" or 2) "the richest and most powerful of those who lived in Judah."
